text: welcome to the introduction to mie
with amazon translate i'm alex and in
this episode we will look at how media
insights engine
uses amazon translates neural machine
translation
to streamline your media processing
applications by automatically generating
and translating video subtitles
this is the last video in our four-part
tutorial series for amazon translate
if you're interested in learning more
about amazon translate please explore
the rest of this series
providing information to customers
partners and colleagues
is essential language gaps can slow or
complicate this process
when your company uses video to pass
information you need a way to quickly
and easily reach speakers of multiple
different languages
that's where the media insights engine
can help the media insights engine or
mie for short is a development framework
for building serverless applications
that process video images
audio and text on aws developers can
interact with mie through rest apis to
build their applications
the media insights engine framework and
several sample applications that use the
framework are hosted on github
the potential use cases for mie are
endless
some examples are content search
localization
with subtitles and translations
marketing and advertising
moderation and compliance and creating
personalized video
viewing experiences for building other
applications with mie the repository
contains an implementation guide
that will help you through the process
today we'd like to specifically focus
on the amazon translate use cases
leveraging amazon translate mie can be
used to automatically generate
and translate subtitles into any
language supported by amazon translate
we can also provide translated
transcriptions of foreign language media
to enable media derived text analytics
and more
so let's get started to deploy the
content localization application
and mie make sure you're signed in to
the aws management console in the us
west 2 region
then navigate to the aws media insights
content localization project on github
scroll down to find the launch stack
buttons located in the installation
section of the readme file
then click on the launch doc button
clicking on the launch deck button will
load the cloud formation template for
the application and for media insights
engine
into the aws cloud formation console
click next on the create stack page
on the specify stack details page you'll
need to name your stack
use a name that is short less than eight
characters is best
because this name will be used to create
unique resource names throughout the
stack
and they can get pretty long if you use
a long stack name
in the parameters section fill in the
admin email parameter
this is the email that the stack will
use to send you the credentials for the
web application
when the deployment is complete we can
leave the rest of the parameters as the
default values
on the configure stack options page
leave everything as default and click
next and finally on the review page
acknowledge that the template will
create aws
identity and access management resources
and once you're ready
click create stack to deploy the stack
you can view the status of the stack
deployment in the aws cloud formation
console
in the status column after about 15 to
30 minutes you should see a status of
create complete
i have another stack deployed to work
with if you like you can pause the video
here
and wait for your stack to deploy and
then follow along
once your stack deploy is complete you
will receive an email with a link to the
stack and credentials to log in to the
web application
i'm going to use the link in the cloud
formation console to navigate to my
stack
this is the stack that i deployed
previously and i'm just going to click
on the stack
and then navigate to the outputs tab and
i'm going to find the key called content
localization solution
the value is the cloudfront url for my
web application
i'm going to click on that and that will
load the application in the browser
so i've already logged into the web
application
but when you log in for the first time
you'll get a login dialog
and you'll use your credentials from the
email you received and you'll be
prompted to change your password
at that point and once that's done you
should see this page
now that we've launched mi stack and
accessed our web application
let's get started analyzing some media
content with our engine
from the collection page navigate to the
upload page of the application
using the menus at the top for this
tutorial we're going to be using
a video from nasa about preparations for
the perseverance mission to mars
we'll use mie to analyze the video and
generate russian subtitles for it
click on the choose file box to upload
the video
once we've added our file we can select
configure workflow to let
the app know what we want to do with the
video as you can see there are a number
of options for how the engine can
analyze the media
in our case we'll focus on using the
audio operators to transcribe the audio
to text and generate the subtitles
under text operators we'll select
translate
and specify the target language for the
new videos
in this case we're selecting russian
once we confirm that we're happy with
the selected parameters we can click
start workflow the time it takes to
complete your workflow depends on the
size of your media file
once the file uploads you can follow the
progress by clicking on the status at
the bottom of the page
or navigate to the collection tab to
view the most recent workflow results
for each video in your collection
clicking on the link in the status
column will take you to the real-time
state machine event monitor
if you'd really like to take a look
under the hood while this file is being
processed
the status for the workflow will be
complete when the workflow is done
once the output file is ready select
analyze on the collection page to review
and further develop the results in the
content analysis page select the
translation tab
under speech recognition to review the
generated subtitles
since we didn't use any custom
terminology or active custom
translation in our workflow some terms
may need manual updates to ensure the
output matches our desired translation
in the content
as you can see here the russian word for
perseverance has been used in the
translation
but we want the name of the mission
which is the english word perseverance
to edit this we can simply click on the
subtitle
and change the word to perseverance
and then we can just click on save edits
to save our edits
the subtitle corrections you save here
will only update the result of this
workflow
this is nice but nasa has a lot of
videos about the perseverance mission
to customize amazon translate to always
use the english word for perseverance
when it encounters the reference to the
perseverance mission
we can use a custom terminology click on
save terminology
at the bottom of the page this will open
a new window where we can create a
custom terminology
to be used with amazon translate we can
use this terminology file
in future mie workflows so amazon
translate knows our preferred terms
in this case we will replace the russian
translation of perseverance
with the english word and then
we'll simply click save
you can see up here that we can use
existing terminologies and edit them
from this dialog
as well and you can see i've already
created a terminology for the
perseverance mission
now when i run more workflows i can
reference this terminology and it will
automatically replace the english word
perseverance with the name of the
mission in the russian translation
so additionally we can make more direct
edits in the script
and when we're happy with the results we
can click save edits
to review the completed subtitles file
you can download the files
in either webvt or srt formats
the content localization application
uses amazon translate batch translation
when you add parallel data to a batch
translation job you can create
active custom translation jobs when you
run these jobs
amazon translate uses your parallel data
at runtime to produce customized machine
translation output
it adapts the translation to reflect the
style tone and word choices that it
finds in your parallel data
with parallel data you can tailor your
translations for terms or phrases that
are unique to a specific domain
such as life sciences law or finance
so let's run a workflow to create
translated russian subtitles with the
same video we used in the last section
this time we'll use parallel data to
customize the results of amazon
translate to fit our domain
from the upload page we will use the
same settings but we will add a parallel
data input
so our settings are to transcribe an
english input generate subtitles
translate to russian and this time we're
going to change the job slightly by
selecting a parallel data set
that i've already created called
perseverance
which is an english to russian data set
and let's also
see what happens when we run the job
using the custom terminology that we
created before
so that one was a perseverance mission
custom terminology
so now that we've selected our settings
we'll just start the workflow and see
what we get
while the workflow is running let's take
a look at the parallel data input
you can create parallel data objects in
amazon translate by inputting samples of
the translated phrases
in csb tmx or tsv format
my input is in csv format the parallel
data consists of examples of phrases in
the source language
in our case english and then the
resulting translated phrases in the
target language which in our case is
russian
so this doesn't have to be the exact
same phrases that are in your content
they're just examples i've already run a
job with and without parallel data so we
don't need to wait for this job to
complete
so if we take a look at our collection
you can see that i've run these two jobs
i've downloaded the resulting subtitles
in russian so that we can compare them
let's take a look at the comparison of
the russian subtitles that were
generated
with and without using parallel data and
custom terminology
on the left is the result without
parallel data
this is the job that we ran in the
previous section of this tutorial
and then on the right is the result with
parallel data and with custom
terminology
the first difference we can see here is
the russian translation for the word
perseverance
it's been replaced with the english name
of the mission
and that change came from the custom
terminology that we created
and then there's a couple of other
subtitles that have changed
these are due to the active custom
translation that was used with the
parallel data
input so i'm just going to re-translate
these back to english to give us english
speakers an
idea of what's different in these
translations
so without the parallel data this
translation was the demands we have for
this mission are extremely difficult
and with the parallel data the
translation was the requirements we have
for this mission are very demanding
so you can see that this is just a
change in the tone and style of the
translation and it better reflects what
was in our parallel data files
in this case both of these are actually
correct translations
it's just that we're using the parallel
data is just impacting the style and the
tone of the translation
so i hope this gives you an idea what
you can do with custom terminologies and
parallel data
in order to increase the accuracy of
translations for your domain
if you want to learn more about active
custom translation please watch
episode 3 of this series customize your
translation output
that's it in this tutorial we deployed
the media insights engine framework
and the content localization application
and used it to automatically create
translated subtitles with amazon
transcribe
and amazon translate with amazon
translate's active custom translation
feature
you can customize amazon translate's
neural machine translation
to provide better accuracy for your
content
